um but before I get into that I'm just
going to talk a little bit about how we
did um the comparison of images in
malware um as we were working through
them we we quickly found that one does
not simply compare the images extracted
from malware um trying to do things as
simple as md5 uh hash matching um tends
not to work because images get changed
in compression um the resolution gets
distorted um and they can also be
changed deliberately by attackers trying
to evade such a technique um so the
algorithm we used is called average hash
and it's a very simple um kind of
algorithm computationally um which is
good because we're running this across
thousands of samples um and just to walk
you guys through it um you start with an
icon like this PDF um icon you reduce it
to gray scale and then you stretch or
Shrink it to a 32x 32 pixel resolution
and then you can conver it to high
contrast um so in order to do this you
get the average value of all the pixels
which is just um you know some value
between 0 and 255 depending on how um
what shade of grade is for each pixel um
add all that up divide by the total
number of pixels pretty um Elementary
and then for each pixel if it's above
that average we set it to 255 um so in
this example the light gray pixel
becomes white and if it's below the
average or equal to it um then we set it
to zero so we make the dark gray pixel
black um
what you end up with is this
monochromatic Masterpiece which is a
pretty Far Cry from the image we started
with but this is actually good for us
because even if we start with this
crummy low reses version um you know
that's all blurry and kind of distorted
we end up with a relatively similar um
representation in average hash um and
this is ideal for trying to apply things
like machine learning um you need it all
to be kind of in the same representation
um we we evaluated average has average
hash compared to md5 um and we so to do
this we uh hand clustered 200 M samples
in terms of whether or not they had
similar images and we found that md5 had
better Precision which means basically
it got less things wrong but um average
hash had better recall which means it
got more things right um and that may be
a little confusing if if your statistics
are Rusty um just to to walk you through

because to to a human um it's it's

and you can kind of visually ignore that
um the the alternative if we were to

false positive so good for md5 um but
md5 also wouldn't get the degraded um
kind of near duplicate it would only get
that near that exact match and um the
the near duplicates are really kind of
what we're we're trying to get at here
um so
we we favor the kind of flexibility of
average hash even if it leads to some
false
positives so um for our first experiment

Trojans
um so um the the problem's a little bit

comparing sets of images in M samples um
so we want to recogniz when there's a
missing image in one of the sets uh so
the formula we use is the number of
matching pairs which in this example is
two um divided by the number of possible
matching pairs which in this example is
three um which gives us a 0.67 um
similarity score in this example um so
we're we're kind of penalizing the score
here because sample a isn't providing

lonely Kitty in Sample B and that's just

used um Google image search results so
um we basically had a different key term
for all the different categories we

mostly Internet Explorer icons with a

the idea here is if you have you know a

image and get a bunch of kind of

you get a bunch of examples of of the
category that you're looking for and
then you can begin to do um matching
with the images found in
malware um so the way we did that
matching was using machine learning um
we used a variety of different
techniques I'm going to walk you guys
through through a super simple algorithm
known as K nearest neighbors just to
give you kind of the intuition um behind
it um and this is kind of uh a textbook
example just to to get the idea so um if
you imagine a graph where the x-axis is
the number of rooms and the Y AIS is the
square footage in in somebody's home um
and then you went around you asked a
bunch of people okay what how many rooms
are in your home what's the square
footage and do you live in an apartment
or a house and then you graft those
points
okay and then then you ask somebody the
number of rooms and square footage and
they told you but for some reason they
were really paranoid and they didn't
want you to know if they lived in a
house or an apartment not the most
relevant example but um the idea here
would be that you would pick the K
nearest neighbors uh where K is just
some integer as appropriate for your
data um so in this example I picked
three um and so you look at the three
nearest neighbors um and you just take
the majority vote so we have two houses
one apartment so we figured out Mr
paranoid lives in a house and he's not
very happy about
that so applying that to um to our
problem um one of the things we tried
was kind of classifying them by
classifying images by their color
